text: (upbeat music)

- We have this vision of
no memory left behind.

We are building a private
social network using AWS
and all of its wonderful microservices,
so that all of your photos, videos,
and other cherish memories.
You'll never lose them.

We built a minimally viable
product our MVP on AWS,

using basic services such
as Cognito and S3 and EC2
and many Lambda functions.

We have a secure login where
a customer can enjoy all
of their memories.
And so photos, video, streaming video

at any time from any
internet connected location.

We've already tested what
we can do with Textract.

So when we scan a photo,
it can have a whole bunch
of handwriting on the backside,
Textract converts that to text obviously

and then embeds it in the
description on Heirloom.
And so someone can simply say,
"hey Heirloom photo Christmas, 1976,"

with handwriting on the back,
it comes up on Heirloom.
You'd think it'd be overwhelming.
So, you know, AWS, this enormous company.

How are they going to
help my little startup?
And yet the engagement with everyone
that I've worked with with AWS
has totally proven that wrong.

And so it was, "you've got a
problem, we've got some tools.
We would like to help you build something
to solve that problem."
The fact that we didn't have
to create our own data centers
or racks of servers or develop this code.
Some of the code had been developed

for other purposes and now
has a commercial application.
And so we can now reap the benefit of it.
We want to leave no memory left behind

and actually enlighten those
old memories that we have

and add new information,
add metadata to that memory.

We believe that it's possible
to have a meta memory.

And so by connecting all
of those memories together
we make each memory much more powerful.
(upbeat music)
